facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 245 of 1964 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 245 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 13, 1963, of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 8 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated February 13, 1963, of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 8 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 13, 1963, of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 8 of 1963. V. Viswanatha Sastri and D.N. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Subba Rao, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J. On or about October 2, 1879, the Corporation of the town of Calcutta incorporated under Bengal Act IV of 1876 entered into an agreement in writing with Dillwyn Parrish, Alfrest Parrish and Robinson Souttar,

facts.text: On or about October 2, 1879, the Corporation of the town of Calcutta incorporated under Bengal Act IV of 1876 entered into an agreement with Dillwyn Parrish, Alfrest Parrish and Robinson Souttar granting right to construct, maintain and use tramways on payment of rents.

anchor.surface_text: On or about October 2, 1879, the Corporation of the town of Calcutta incorporated under Bengal Act IV of 1876 entered into an agreement in writing with Dillwyn Parrish, Alfrest Parrish and Robinson Souttar, hereinafter called the grantees whereunder the Corporation granted to the said grantees the right to construct, maintain and use certain tramways in Calcutta on payment of certain rents as provided in the said agreement The agreement contained an arbitration clause which provided for referring any disputes arising under the said agreement to arbitration in the manner prescribed thereunder.

facts.text: The 1879 agreement contained an arbitration clause for referring disputes to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement contained an arbitration clause which provided for referring any disputes arising under the said agreement to arbitration in the manner prescribed thereunder. The said agreement further provided in cl. 28 that the words the said Corporation would include the Corporation and its successors.

facts.text: Clause 28 of the 1879 agreement provided that 'the said Corporation' includes the Corporation and its successors.

anchor.surface_text: The said agreement further provided in cl. 28 that the words the said Corporation would include the Corporation and its successors. Different agreements were entered into between the successors of the Corporation of Calcutta and the grantees from time to time, namely, on November 22, 1879, September 2, 1893 and December 9, 1899, and were confirmed by appropriate Acts.

facts.text: Subsequent agreements entered on November 22, 1879, September 2, 1893 and December 9, 1899, confirmed by Acts.

anchor.surface_text: Different agreements were entered into between the successors of the Corporation of Calcutta and the grantees from time to time, namely, on November 22, 1879, September 2, 1893 and December 9, 1899, and were confirmed by appropriate Acts. In all these agreements the appellants predecessor-in-interest agreed to pay the rents to the respondents predecessors-in-interest in respect of the tramways constructed, maintained and used by them.

facts.text: All agreements contained similar arbitration clauses.

anchor.surface_text: All the said agreements contained an arbitration clause similar to that contained in the first agreement.

facts.text: Corporation of Calcutta constituted by Bengal Act II of 1888 is successor of properties of Corporation of the town of Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation of Calcutta is now the successor of the properties of the Corporation of the town of Calcutta constituted under the Bengal Act IV of 1876. It was constituted by Bengal Act II of 1888.

facts.text: Calcutta Tramways Co. Ltd. (appellant) is the successor or assignee of the grantees.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, i.e., the Calcutta Tramways Co. Ltd., is the successor or the assignee of the said grantees.

facts.text: On August 30, 1951, State of West Bengal entered into agreement with appellant to purchase the undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: On August 30, 1951, the State of West Bengal entered into an agreement with the appellant whereby the Government agreed to purchase the undertaking of the appellant as provided in the said agreement.

facts.text: Calcutta Tramways Act, 1951 (W.B. Act XXV of 1951) came into effect on October 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta Tramways Act, 1951 (W.B. Act XXV of 1951) was passed and it came into effect on October 18, 1951.

facts.text: Under the 1951 Act, Government of West Bengal was substituted for the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements, with reservation that sums payable remain payable to the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Under that Act the Government of West Bengal was practically substituted for the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements subject to a reservation that any sums payable under the said agreements shall be payable by the appellant to the Corporation

facts.text: Disputes arose regarding track rent payable by appellant to the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose as regards the track rent payable by the appellant to the Corporation and the dispute was referred to arbitration in accordance with the terms of the arbitration clause.

facts.text: Dispute was referred to arbitration per arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose as regards the track rent payable by the appellant to the Corporation and the dispute was referred to arbitration in accordance with the terms of the arbitration clause.

facts.text: Parties appointed arbitrators per arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: Though the parties appointed arbitrators in terms of the arbitration clause of the agreements, the appellant nominated its arbitrator without prejudice to its rights

facts.text: Appellant filed application on January 7, 1963, in Original Side of Calcutta High Court questioning validity of arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: and filed on January 7, 1963, an application in the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court, inter alia, for the determination of the question whether there was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent and for other incidental reliefs.

facts.text: A.N. Ray, J. of Calcutta High Court held that there was a valid arbitration agreement, appellant was party to arbitration clauses, reference valid.

anchor.surface_text: The application was heard by A.N. Ray, J. who held that there was an agreement between the appellant and the respondent and that the appellant was a party to the arbitration clauses contained in the relevant agreements, that the respondent could make a reference to arbitration in terms of the said agreements and that the reference to the arbitrators was valid, legal and effective.

facts.text: Appellant filed present appeal by special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, by special leave, has filed the present appeal against the said order of the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant contended that all rights of Corporation under agreements transferred to Government of West Bengal under 1951 Act except sums payable.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A.V. Viswanatha Shastri, learned counsel for the appellant, contended that all the rights of the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements stood transferred under the Tramways Act, 1951, and vested in the Government of West Bengal except only in regard to the sums payable to the Corporation

facts.text: Supreme Court held that arbitration clauses remain enforceable by Corporation for sums payable.

anchor.surface_text: On such a construction we hold, as we have indicated earlier, that both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved thereunder.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 13, 1963, of the Calcutta High Court
incorporated under Bengal Act IV of 1876 entered into an agreement in writing with Dillwyn Parrish, Alfrest Parrish

concepts.unlisted_description: Act incorporating Corporation of the town of Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: Bengal Act II of 1888. The appellant, i.e., the Calcutta Tramways Co. Ltd., is the successor or the assignee
The Calcutta Tramways Act, 1951 (W.B. Act XXV of 1951) was passed and it came into effect on October 18, 1951.

concepts.unlisted_label: Calcutta Tramways Act, 1951 (W.B. Act XXV of 1951)
concepts.unlisted_description: Act substituting Government for Corporation in tramway agreements

concepts.interpretation: Confirms the transfer agreement of August 30, 1951 between State and appellant.
Transfers powers and duties re tramways to Government notwithstanding other laws.
Substitutes Government in agreements subject to proviso saving sums payable to Corporation as if Act not passed, preserving both substantive right and arbitration procedure.
concepts.unlisted_description: Substitution of Government in agreements with proviso for sums payable

anchor.surface_text: The agreement contained an arbitration clause which provided for referring any disputes arising under the said agreement to arbitration in the manner prescribed thereunder. The said agreement further provided in cl. 28

concepts.interpretation: Arbitration clauses in agreements remain enforceable by Corporation for disputes over saved sums payable.
concepts.unlisted_description: Clause for referring disputes under tramway agreements to arbitration

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 5 of the Act the Government is statutorily substituted for the respondent or its predecessors-in-interest in the various agreements stated supra. The fiction is a well defined one.

concepts.interpretation: Government replaces Corporation as party unless subject-matter or context otherwise requires; proviso excludes sums payable.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to s. 5 saves from the operation of the substantive section the sums payable under any such agreements to any such bodies mentioned therein it excludes the operation of the fiction in respect of such sums payable.

concepts.interpretation: Saves sums payable as if Act not passed, including connected procedural arbitration right.
concepts.unlisted_description: Proviso excludes operation of fiction for specified matters

concepts.interpretation: Construing proviso to save both right and remedy avoids anomalies.
Arbitration procedure inseparable from right to sums payable.
concepts.unlisted_description: Substantive right and procedural remedy must go together

issues.text: whether there was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent

anchor.surface_text: an application in the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court, inter alia, for the determination of the question whether there was a valid arbitration agreement between the appellant and the respondent and for other incidental reliefs. The application was heared by A.N. Ray, J. who held that there was an agreement between the appellant and the respondent

issues.text: whether the Corporation could rely on the arbitration clauses of the agreements and refer the disputes arising in respect of the sums payable in terms of the said agreements to arbitration

anchor.surface_text: the Corporation could not rely on the arbitration clauses of the agreements and refer the disputes arising in respect of the sums payable in terms of the said agreements to arbitration. The point raised is in a small compass and turns upon the relevant provisions of the West Bengal Act XXV of 1951, hereinafter called the Act. Under the Act the agreement entered into on August 30, 1951

arguments.claim: All the rights of the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements stood transferred under the Tramways Act, 1951, and vested in the Government of West Bengal except only in regard to the sums payable to the Corporation and therefore the Corporation could not rely on the arbitration clauses of the agreements and refer the disputes arising in respect of the sums payable in terms of the said agreements to arbitration

anchor.surface_text: all the rights of the Corporation of Calcutta under the various agreements stood transferred under the Tramways Act, 1951, and vested in the Government of West Bengal except only in regard to the sums payable to the Corporation and that, therefore, the Corporation could not rely on the arbitration clauses of the agreements and refer the disputes arising in respect of the sums payable in terms of the said agreements to arbitration.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso to s.5 saves sums payable as if Act not passed, preserving agreements intact including arbitration procedure; substantive right and remedy interconnected

arguments.claim: There was an agreement between the appellant and the respondent and that the appellant was a party to the arbitration clauses contained in the relevant agreements, that the respondent could make a reference to arbitration in terms of the said agreements and that the reference to the arbitrators was valid, legal and effective

anchor.surface_text: who held that there was an agreement between the appellant and the respondent and that the appellant was a party to the arbitration clauses contained in the relevant agreements, that the respondent could make a reference to arbitration in terms of the said agreements and that the reference to the arbitrators was valid, legal and effective.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court upholds by dismissing appeal and confirming arbitration clauses remain enforceable

arguments.claim: The proviso to s. 5 saves from the operation of the substantive section the sums payable under any such agreements to any such bodies mentioned therein; it excludes the operation of the fiction in respect of such sums payable; in respect of the said sums payable the agreements entered into with the said bodies will remain intact as if the Act had not been passed

The substantive right to the payment of rent and the procedural one to have any dispute arising in respect of that right referred to arbitration embodied in the agreements are interconnected and are not severable. To preserve the substantive right and to withhold the procedural right to enforce it is to save the right and to deny the remedy

To accept the contention of the appellant is to make out a new agreement between the parties in respect of the sums payable. The acceptance of this suggestion compels the Corporation to give up its agreed remedy

The alternative suggestion, namely, that in respect of the amounts payable to the Corporation the arbitration clauses of the agreements could be enforced by the Government against the appellant introduces an incongruity. While the dispute would be between the appellant and the Corporation, the arbitration would be between the appellant and a third party
The argument that the Government would be acting as a trustee of the Corporation in respect of the sums payable to the Corporation is not supported by any of the provisions of the Act
A fair construction of the proviso to s. 5 of the Act removes all the anomalies

In the substantive part of s. 5 of the Act the fiction takes effect unless the subject-matter or the context otherwise requires. The proviso in terms as well as by necessary implication brings the subject-matter of the sums payable under the agreements both under the substantive and procedural aspects within the scope of the said exception
On such a construction we hold... that both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved thereunder

holdings.text: The proviso to s. 5 saves from the operation of the substantive section the sums payable under any such agreements to any such bodies mentioned therein it excludes the operation of the fiction in respect of such sums payable. In respect of the said sums payable the agreements entered into with the said bodies will remain intact as if the Act had not been passed that is to say, the respondent would still continue to be a party to the said agreements for the said purpose.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso operates as exception to statutory fiction of substitution, preserving original agreements and parties for subject of sums payable.

holdings.text: The substantive right to the payment of rent and the procedural one to have any dispute arising in respect of that right referred to arbitration embodied in the agreements are interconnected and are not severable. To preserve the substantive right and to withhold the procedural right to enforce it is to save the right and to deny the remedy.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Saved substantive right to sums payable necessarily includes associated procedural arbitration remedy under original agreements; severing them illogical.

holdings.text: On such a construction we hold, as we have indicated earlier, that both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved thereunder.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory construction of s.5 proviso alongside substantive part preserves both right to payments and arbitration procedure against Corporation; upholds validity of reference.

holdings.text: The argument that the Government would be acting as a trustee of the Corporation in respect of the sums payable to the Corporation is not supported by any of the provisions of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual support in Act for implying trusteeship to enable Government enforcement of arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: On such a companystruction we hold, as we have indicated earlier, that both the right to the said sums payable and the procedure of arbitration are saved thereunder.

outcome.relief_summary: The right to sums payable and arbitration procedure saved for the Corporation; appellant's contention rejected, upholding High Court order on validity of arbitration agreement and reference
